docs.snippet: IT looks so ordinary. Men are sitting in a small white room on the floor near some gray, flowered throw pillows. They are laughing, drinking, eating with their hands, adjusting their turbans. A visitor identified in the transcript as a sheik sits ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT looks so ordinary. Men are sitting in a small white room on the floor near some gray, flowered throw pillows. They are laughing, drinking, eating with their hands, adjusting their turbans. A visitor identified in the transcript as a sheik sits next to Osama bin Laden. He exclaims what a nice pad Mr. bin Laden has, how clean and comfortable the guest quarters are. The tape of Mr. bin Laden describing the attacks of Sept. 11, despite frequent invocations of Allah, is stunningly mundane. Mr. bin Laden uses gentle hand motions to narrate. ''We calculated in advance the number of casualties from the enemy,'' he says, raising his fingers, as if he were counting people at a party.
docs.abstract: Comment on videotape showing Osama bin Laden describing terrorist attacks of Sept 11, discussing catastrophic events in tone that is seen stunningly mundane; bin Laden and other men are seen joking like schoolboys about the death of thousands; scene seems to describe what Hannah Arendt called 'the word-and-thought-defying banality of evil'; photo (M)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: The Banality of Terror; Dreams of Holy War Over a Quiet Evening

docs.snippet: NO one knew last week whether Osama bin Laden had moved to Pakistan; he hadn't sent out change-of-address cards. But the war certainly began to shift there -- to a country where the terrain is more hospitable than Tora Bora, but the politics are a...
docs.lead_paragraph: NO one knew last week whether Osama bin Laden had moved to Pakistan; he hadn't sent out change-of-address cards. But the war certainly began to shift there -- to a country where the terrain is more hospitable than Tora Bora, but the politics are a lot less forgiving for Americans. It is, President Bush's aides acknowledge, a taste of what's to come in Phase 2 of the war on terror. Distinctions between friend and foe will be a lot harder to make than they were just weeks ago in Afghanistan.
docs.abstract: War in Afghanistan is shifting to terrain that is more hospitable than Tora Bora, but politics are much less forgiving for Americans; distinctions between friend and foe will be harder to make than they were just weeks ago in Afghanistan; war seems certain to become increasingly uncomfortable for some Washington allies--notably Pakistan, where military government has unpleasant recent history of making covert use of its terrorist friends in battle to control Kashmir; real definitional challenge will come as Pres Bush expands war to deal with states that may not be sponsoring terrorism, but are developing nuclear and biological weapons that could fall into hands of terrorists, such as Iraq and North Korea; photo (M)

headline.main: The World; As the Battlefield Changes, So Does the War Itself

docs.snippet: The Bush administration, frustrated that the Indonesian government has failed to crack down against the threat of terrorism, has urged officials here to begin a search for an Indonesian cleric believed to be the point man for Al Qaeda in Southeast...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration, frustrated that the Indonesian government has failed to crack down against the threat of terrorism, has urged officials here to begin a search for an Indonesian cleric believed to be the point man for Al Qaeda in Southeast Asia, American officials said. The officials contrast the help in fighting terrorism that they are receiving from Singapore, Malaysia and the Philippines with what they characterize as a lack of energetic cooperation from Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim country. The C.I.A. said last week that Indonesia was a likely place for Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's organization, to base further operations.
docs.abstract: Bush administration, frustrated that Indonesia has not cracked down on terrorist threat, urges officials to hunt for Indonesian cleric, Riudan Isamuddin or Hambali, who is believed to be Al Qaeda point man in Southeast Asia; US believes he led plot to blow up US Embassy in Singapore; Indonesians also say they do not have enough evidence to arest second cleric, Abu Bakar Baasyir, alleged conduit of money (M)

headline.main: Finding a Tepid Ally in the War on Terror, U.S. Presses Indonesia to Arrest 2 Clerics

byline.original: By RAYMOND BONNER and JANE PERLEZ

docs.snippet: At a pivotal moment in the siege of Kunduz late last month, a Northern Alliance commander urgently requested American airstrikes against several hundred Taliban soldiers and tanks massing on a ridge more than a mile from the city. He pleaded that ...
docs.lead_paragraph: At a pivotal moment in the siege of Kunduz late last month, a Northern Alliance commander urgently requested American airstrikes against several hundred Taliban soldiers and tanks massing on a ridge more than a mile from the city. He pleaded that the attack be launched within 24 hours. A Special Operations ground spotter immediately radioed an American command center in Saudi Arabia, which ordered a nearby B-52 to rain 16 cluster bombs on the enemy forces. Flying at 30,000 feet, the bomber never saw its prey. But the spotter used a laser pointer to guide the bombs, which carried new devices that kept them on course through buffeting winds, enabling them to spew antiarmor bomblets with deadly precision.
docs.abstract: Guidance systems employed in US airstrikes in Afghanistan make them devastatingly accurate; satellites, electronic-eavesdropping planes and human ground spotters are working together more reliably than ever, enabling distant commanders to direct warplanes to targets with stunning speed and accuracy; Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners confirm that precise bombing from planes they often could not hear or see broke will of battle-hardened troops; relatively small number of civilian casualties made possible by pinpoint bombing helps US maintain support of friendly Islamic nations, and air campaign's deadly effectiveness helps embolden opposition commanders; photos; drawing (L)

headline.main: Use of Pinpoint Air Power Comes of Age in New War
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIR CAMPAIGN

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and JAMES DAO

docs.snippet: Ever since Sept. 11, President Bush has used his steady command of the war and his soaring approval ratings to his enormous political advantage. As one aide said not long ago, ''With these kinds of approval ratings, why compromise?''    But this w...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since Sept. 11, President Bush has used his steady command of the war and his soaring approval ratings to his enormous political advantage. As one aide said not long ago, ''With these kinds of approval ratings, why compromise?'' But this week Mr. Bush has found himself compromising plenty. On a variety of policy and personnel issues he is even in the odd position of playing defense at home while continuing on the offense against Al Qaeda.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush's approval ratings since Sept 11 continue to soar in h is handling of war on terrorism, but at home he faces variety of policy and personnel issues; list of recent annoyances, compromises and minor battles lost continues to grow; in addition, news of policy differences is beginning to leak out of White House as Bush's circle of appointees spreads far beyond loyal corps that has been with him since presidential campaign or before that, since he was governor (M)

headline.main: White House Memo; Bush Is Still Winning War There, But He Begins to Lose Battles Here

docs.snippet: Vice President Dick Cheney opened a four-day campaign-style swing through California today by underscoring America's resolve to stop Iraq, Iran and North Korea from continuing to develop or pursue nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.    In a s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Dick Cheney opened a four-day campaign-style swing through California today by underscoring America's resolve to stop Iraq, Iran and North Korea from continuing to develop or pursue nuclear, chemical or biological weapons. In a speech to 2,500 marines at this sprawling base north of San Diego, Mr. Cheney defended President Bush's decision to single out those three countries as an ''axis of evil,'' defining a new phase in Washington's war against terror. Some allies have criticized Mr. Bush's language.
docs.abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney opens four-day campaign-style swing through California by underscoring America's resolve to stop Iraq, Iran and North Korea from continuing to develop or pursue nuclear, chemical or biological weapons; address at Marine Corps Air Station in Miramar defends Pres Bush's decision to single out three nations as an 'axis of evil,' defining new phase in Washington's war against terror; photo (M)

headline.main: Cheney, at Marine Base, Reinforces Bush's Stand On War Against Terror
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICE PRESIDENT

docs.snippet: It is the supporters of terrorism in the mountains of Tora Bora who are looking terrified these days. Exhausted and whimpering, vanquished fighters for Osama bin Laden were paraded for the cameras yesterday by their new Afghan jailers as visual ai...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is the supporters of terrorism in the mountains of Tora Bora who are looking terrified these days. Exhausted and whimpering, vanquished fighters for Osama bin Laden were paraded for the cameras yesterday by their new Afghan jailers as visual aids for the continuing story of Al Qaeda on the run. Still, day after day, one element of the story remains maddeningly elusive, as far as the United States and the rest of the coalition is concerned: Where is Mr. bin Laden hiding?
docs.abstract: Overview of events in war on terrorism, including continuing search for Osama bin Laden, and for Taliban's chieftain, Mullah Muhammad Omar, and efforts to clear northern Afghanistan of underground carpet of land mines laid out during 22 years of war (M)

headline.main: Tora Bora Perp Walk, Fugitives on the Fly, Conflicting War Aims
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 17, 2001

docs.snippet: In the summer of 1975, with the cold war raging and the memory of Saigon's fall terribly fresh, the United States sponsored a covert operation to prevent another Communist takeover, this time across the world, in Angola.    The effort failed to ke...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1975, with the cold war raging and the memory of Saigon's fall terribly fresh, the United States sponsored a covert operation to prevent another Communist takeover, this time across the world, in Angola. The effort failed to keep a Marxist government from taking power but ushered in a long and chaotic civil war, involving American, Chinese and Russian interests, and Cuban and South African soldiers.
docs.abstract: US involvement in Angola from 1970's reviewed (M)

headline.main: From Old Files, a New Story Of U.S. Role in Angolan War

docs.snippet: The top Marine general for Central Asia and the Persian Gulf is moving his headquarters to Bahrain from Hawaii, joining Army, Navy and Air Force counterparts who have already uprooted from peacetime postings in the United States to set up battle s...
docs.lead_paragraph: The top Marine general for Central Asia and the Persian Gulf is moving his headquarters to Bahrain from Hawaii, joining Army, Navy and Air Force counterparts who have already uprooted from peacetime postings in the United States to set up battle stations in the region, military officials said today. Even as the war in Afghanistan fitfully winds down, the moves suggest future operations against terrorism in the 25-nation region spanning the Red Sea to the Indian Ocean that makes up the Central Command.
docs.abstract: Lt Gen Earl B Hailston, top marine general for Central Asia and Persian Gulf is moving headquarters to Bahrain from Hawaii, joining Army, Navy and Air Force counterparts who have already uprooted from peacetime postings in US to set up battle stations in region; map (M)

headline.main: Top U.S. Military Commanders Are Transferred Closer to the War Zone

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and JAMES DAO

docs.snippet: For all the substance Pittsburgh offers when it takes the court, there are times when the Panthers are flashy, energetic and high flying.     The buzzing Madison Square Garden crowd will get one more entertaining look at these Panthers....
docs.lead_paragraph: For all the substance Pittsburgh offers when it takes the court, there are times when the Panthers are flashy, energetic and high flying. The buzzing Madison Square Garden crowd will get one more entertaining look at these Panthers.
docs.abstract: Pittsburgh University defeats Miami University, 76-71, in Big East tournament semifinals; photos (M)
